awd_titl_txt: Conference: Aspen Winter Conference: Disorder and Quantum Phases of Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation of researchers at the Winter 2023 Aspen Conference “Disorder and Quantum Phases of Matter” to be held from 12/10/2023 to 12/15/2023 at the Aspen Center for Physics in Aspen, CO. The conference is expected to draw approximately 80 participants with high attendance from junior (student and postdoc) researchers, 22-24 invited talks, a poster session, and a midday break for informal interactions. The topics covered include strange metals, high Tc superconductivity, quantum phase transitions, localized strongly interacting states of matter, disorder in topological phases, which are all at the forefront of condensed matter physics. The conference will facilitate the exchange of ideas between junior and senior researchers and serve as an opportunity for creating new collaborations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Aspen Center for Physics Winter Conference, held from December 10-15, 2023, brought together leading physicists to explore how disorder in materials affects quantum states. Understanding how disorder influences material properties and the emergence of novel quantum states could lead to breakthroughs in controlling and optimizing quantum materials.

 

Superconductivity, a key phenomenon in many quantum materials, usually arises when electron attraction overcomes repulsion, leading to Cooper pair formation and condensation, allowing supercurrent to flow without resistance at zero temperature. However, disorder and external fields can cause superconductors to transition to exotic states with significant superconducting correlations but without condensation. The conference discussed new paradigms in understanding these states through controlled theoretical models and new experimental investigations using scanning tunneling spectroscopy. In addition, a new mechanism of microwave absorption in superconductors, significantly enhancing AC conductivity, was also discussed, emphasizing the impact of inelastic quasiparticle relaxation time and the orientation of the microwave field relative to the supercurrent. Another study discussed inhomogeneity-induced time-reversal symmetry breaking in cuprate twist junctions. It showed how a random Josephson coupling can generate a global second-harmonic Josephson coupling, leading to spontaneous breaking of time-reversal symmetry. This effect is enhanced by spatial correlations of the coupling, providing an explanation for recent observations in twisted Josephson junctions between high-temperature superconductors.

 

The Berezinskii-Kosterlitz-Thouless (BKT) transition in a semiconductor-superconductor two-dimensional Josephson junction array was also examined. This system exhibits superconducting, anomalous metal, and insulating phases, with the BKT transition temperature dropping to zero at the boundary between the superconducting and anomalous metal phases. Observations in the anomalous metal phase suggest a quantum melting transition involving the destruction of superconducting order by vortex fluctuations.

 

The effect of disorder on topological insulators and superconductors and their surface states was another major topic. Researchers examined surface states in topological insulators and superconductors, focusing on those outside traditional Wigner-Dyson classes. Most non-Wigner-Dyson topological insulators lack the usual spectral flow, meaning surface states can be detached from bulk states and localized by disorder, except at the band center. This fragility contrasts with the robust spectral flow in traditional topological insulators, offering new insights into topological states of matter. Furthermore, the observation of fractional quantum anomalous Hall effects in twisted bilayer MoTe2 at zero magnetic field was presented. Robust ferromagnetic states at fractional fillings provide insights into the interplay between strong electron-electron interactions and topological properties, opening new avenues for exploring topologically non-trivial states and their applications.

 

The conference also discussed disordered electron systems with competing correlated metallic and insulating states. Nonlinear coherent THz electrodynamics of quasiparticles in disordered silicon revealed a "marginal Fermi glass" characterized by strong electron-electron interactions and disorder, paralleling the behavior of marginal Fermi liquids in strongly correlated metals. In addition, the transport properties of state-of-the-art ZnO-based heterostructures at very low temperatures enhance our understanding of the phase diagram around the Wigner crystallization transition in this system.

 

The conference fostered an inclusive and collaborative environment, bringing together a diverse group of researchers, including many early-career and women physicists. Furthermore, the conference featured a public lecture by Erica Carlson, engaging the broader community and sparking interest in quantum materials.

 

Overall, the conference advanced our understanding of superconductivity, topological states, and other quantum phases of matter where disorder can promote new material properties and stabilize certain quantum states that would not exist in a perfectly ordered material. This opens up new possibilities for designing materials with tailored properties. The discussions and collaborations formed during the conference brought a broad range of perspectives, providing a platform for sharing ideas, forming collaborations, and fostering a diverse research community to drive future development of quantum phases of matter.
